msg.data:
Must be used before SparkInterpreter (%spark) initialized
Hint: put this paragraph before any Spark code and restart Zeppelin/Interpreter

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%geometa 
SELECT samples.id, samples.title, samples.gsm, samples.gse, organism, samples.characteristics,
           molecules.molecule, sequencers.model,
           samples.description, samples.treatment_protocol, samples.extract_protocol,
           samples.source_name, samples.data_processing,
           samples.submission_date, samples.last_update_date, samples.status,
           samples.type, samples.contact, samples.gpl
  FROM samples, organisms, molecules, sequencers, LOWER(samples.characteristics) as ch, LOWER(organisms.name) as organism
  WHERE samples.organism_id = organisms.id AND samples.molecule_id = molecules.id AND samples.sequencer_id =  sequencers.id AND (ch like '% age %' OR ch like '% age:%') AND organism like '%sapiens%'

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data: id	title	gsm	gse	organism	characteristics	molecule	model	description	treatment_protocol	extract_protocol	source_name	data_processing	submission_date	last_update_date	status	type	contact	gpl

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%geometa
          SELECT gsm.title AS title, gsm.gsm, gsm.series_id AS gse, gsm.gpl,
                 sequencers.id AS sequencer_id, molecules.id as molecule_id, gsm.organism_ch1 AS organism_id,
                 gsm.characteristics_ch1,
                 gsm.status, gsm.submission_date, gsm.last_update_date, gsm.type, gsm.source_name_ch1 AS source,
                 gsm.treatment_protocol_ch1 AS treatment_protocol, gsm.extract_protocol_ch1 AS extract_protocol,
                 gsm.description, gsm.data_processing, gsm.contact
               FROM gsm, gpl, sequencers, molecules, TRIM(SUBSTRING(LOWER(gpl.title), 0, POSITION('(' IN gpl.title))) as sequencer
               WHERE gsm.gpl = gpl.gpl AND
                 gpl.technology = 'high-throughput sequencing' AND
                 sequencers.model = sequencer AND
                 molecules.molecule = gsm.molecule_ch1 AND
                 gsm.organism_ch1 like '%sapiens%' AND (gsm.characteristics_ch1 like '% age %' OR gsm.characteristics_ch1 like '% age:%' )
               LIMIT 30

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

title	gsm	gse	gpl	sequencer_id	molecule_id	organism_id	characteristics_ch1	status	submission_date	last_update_date	type	source	treatment_protocol	extract_protocol	description	data_processing	contact
Healthy non-smoker (NS_Illumina)	GSM718707	GSE29006,GSE29007	GPL10999	25	6	Homo sapiens	cell type: large airway epithelial cells; gender: 3 Female; average age: 29.7; smoking status: 3 Never; lung cancer: 3 No	Public on Jun 01 2011	2011-05-02	2013-05-23	SRA	Large airway epithelial cells	null	Standard Illumina mRNA-seq Protocol (Paired end 75 bp reads, fragments were 300bp, 2 50 bp adapter sequences, 2 75 bp reads, and a 50 bp insert (sd= 50bp) or prototype NuGEN Ovation RNA-seq protocol (36 bp single end reads)	Standard Illumina mRNA-seq Protocol, 75 bp paired-end sequencing	Reads were aligned to human genome build 19 using Tophat software v1.0.14 with mammalian defaults with the exception of specifying a maximum of 10 multi-reads.  Gene expression measurements (RPKM, reads per kilobase per million reads) were calculated based on the alignments using Scripture software's score function.  The annotation file used by Scripture software was based on Ensembl v59 (n=49,702 genes) where the union set of transcripts mapping to a single gene was used to summarize gene-level expression.  The FWER corrected p-value for the observed read count across the transcript (Scripture software) was used to decide if a gene confidently expressed in a sample (p-value < 0.05 were designated as present).	Name: Avrum  Spira; Email: aspira@lung.bumc.bu.edu; Phone: 617-638-4860; Fax: 617-536-8093; Laboratory: Pulmonomics Lab; Department: Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine; Institute: Boston University Medical Center; Address: 715 Albany Street, R304; City: Boston; State: MA; Zip/postal_code: 02118; Country: USA; Web_link: http://www.pulmonomics.org

Healthy non-smoker	GSM814536	GSE32726,GSE48798	GPL9138	16	6	Homo sapiens	Sex: 3 Female; average age: 29.7; smoking status: 3 Never; lung cancer: 3 No	Public on Oct 07 2013	2011-10-12	2013-10-07	SRA	Large airway epithelial cells	null	300ng of small molecular weight fraction (<200bp) RNA was pooled from individuals within each phenotype, never smoker (NS), current smoker (S), no cancer (NC) and cancer (C), for a total of 4 samples (900ng each).  Each pooled sample was size fractioned using the Ambion flashPAGE fractionator to obtain small RNAs of 10-40nts. Small RNA sequencing libraries were created using SOLiD Small RNA Expression Kit (Ambion) starting with 200ng of the size fractionated small RNA following the manufacturer’s instructions.  Libraries were sequenced on an Applied Biosystems SOLiD System to obtain 36 bp reads.	ABI SOLID small RNA-seq, 36 bp sequencing	The adapter was trimmed off of the 3’ end of each read.  Reads were aligned to the human genome build 19 (hg19) using Bowtie version 0.12.3  allowing up to two mismatches and limiting the number of locations a read can map to the genome to 4 or fewer.  The number of reads that overlap with the genomic locations of known mature microRNA from miRBase v16 and from the miRDeep predictions for miR- 4423 was counted using BEDTools v2.9.0.	Name: Avrum Spira; Email: aspira@bu.edu; Laboratory: Spira/Lenburg Lab; Department: Computational Biomedicine; Institute: Boston University; Address: 72 East Concord Street, E631; City: Boston; State: MA; Zip/postal_code: 02118; Country: USA

fetal CEC 1	GSM1020215	GSE41616	GPL11154	29	6	Homo sapiens	cell type: corneal endothelial cells; age: gestation age 16-18wk	Public on Jan 08 2013	2012-10-16	2013-05-22	SRA	corneal endothelial cells	null	RNA were extracted from those adult and fetal tissues using RNeasy Micro Kit (Qiagen, Cat. No. 74004, CA,USA). RNA concentration was detected by nanodrop spectrophotometer; RNA-Seq library construction followed the protocol described in illumina TruSeq™ RNA Sample Preparation Guide.  Library construction was started with 100ng total RNA, via poly-T oligo-attached magnetic beads to purify the poly-A containing mRNA molecules. RNA fragments were reverse transcribed into first stand cDNA, follwed by synthesis  second strand cDNA. After end repaired with a single ‘A’ base, cDNAs were ligated with different adapters for PCR amplification. After amplified for 15 cycles, the concentration of product was tested by the Qubit Fluorometer (Invitrogen, USA).	null	each sample was subjected to sequencing according to manufacturer’s instruction with Illumina Hiseq 2000. Reads were mapped to the hg19 genome using BWA.; For all datasets analyzed, we first transformed transcript read counts to the RPKM metric, and genes with an average RPKM<1 were filtered out, followed by quantile normalization.; Genome_build: hg19; Supplementary_files_format_and_content: filtered and normalized RPKM table	Name: Kevin Huang; Phone: 310-267-0438; Laboratory: Guoping Fan; Department: Human Genetics; Institute: UCLA; Address: Gonda BLDG Rm. 6554, P.O.Box 957088; City: Los Angeles; State: CA; Zip/postal_code: 90095-7088; Country: USA

No. 74004, CA,USA). RNA concentration was detected by nanodrop spectrophotometer; RNA-Seq library construction followed the protocol described in illumina TruSeq™ RNA Sample Preparation Guide.  Library construction was started with 100ng total RNA, via poly-T oligo-attached magnetic beads to purify the poly-A containing mRNA molecules. After end repaired with a single ‘A’ base, cDNAs were ligated with different adapters for PCR amplification. Reads were mapped to the hg19 genome using BWA.; For all datasets analyzed, we first transformed transcript read counts to the RPKM metric, and genes with an average RPKM<1 were filtered out, followed by quantile normalization.; Genome_build: hg19; Supplementary_files_format_and_content: filtered and normalized RPKM table	Name: Kevin Huang; Phone: 310-267-0438; Laboratory: Guoping Fan; Department: Human Genetics; Institute: UCLA; Address: Gonda BLDG Rm. 6554, P.O.Box 957088; City: Los Angeles; State: CA; Zip/postal_code: 90095-7088; Country: USA
WT-82 y iPSC-mDA + Nuclear GFP n 1	GSM1266739	GSE52431	GPL11154	29	6	Homo sapiens	cell type: iPSC-derived midbrain dopamine (mDA) neurons; donor age (years): 82; expression construct: Nuclear GFP	Public on Jan 23 2014	2013-11-15	2014-01-23	SRA	iPSC-derived midbrain dopamine (mDA) neurons	mDA neurons were transfected with modified-RNA expressing either nuclear-GFP or GFP-progerin on 5 consecutive days prior to analysis on day 6.	Cells were lysed directly in Trizol (Life Technologies).   RNA was extracted using chloroform and ethanol precipitation and further cleaned using the miRNeasy kit (Qiagen).; After ribogreen quantification and quality control of Agilent BioAnalyzer, 500ng of total underwent polyA selection and Truseq library preparation according to instruction provided by Illumina (TruSeq™ RNA Sample Prep Kit v2), with 6 cycles of PCR. Samples were barcoded and run on a Hiseq 2000 in a 75bp/75bp Paired end run, using the TruSeq SBS Kit v3 (Illumina).  An average of 74 million paired reads were generated per sample. At the most the ribosomal reads represented 0.3% and the percent of mRNA bases was closed to 55% on average.	null	Basecalls performed using CASAVA version 1.4; Reads were mapped to the human genome (Hg19) using STAR 2.3.0e with default mapping parameters; Read counts were generated from mapped reads using HT-Seq count; Genome_build: Hg19; Supplementary_files_format_and_content: Txt files containing total read counts per gene from HT-Seq counts using mode = "union"	Name: Jeffrey Zhao; Email: zhaoy@mskcc.org; Department: Genomics Core; Institute: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center; Address: 1275 York Avenue; City: New York; State: NY; Zip/postal_code: 10065; Country: USA
WT-82 y iPSC-mDA + Nuclear GFP n 3	GSM1266740	GSE52431	GPL11154	29	6	Homo sapiens	cell type: iPSC-derived midbrain dopamine (mDA) neurons; donor age (years): 82; expression construct: Nuclear GFP	Public on Jan 23 2014	2013-11-15	2014-01-23	SRA	iPSC-derived midbrain dopamine (mDA) neurons	mDA neurons were transfected with modified-RNA expressing either nuclear-GFP or GFP-progerin on 5 consecutive days prior to analysis on day 6.	Cells were lysed directly in Trizol (Life Technologies).   RNA was extracted using chloroform and ethanol precipitation and further cleaned using the miRNeasy kit (Qiagen).; After ribogreen quantification and quality control of Agilent BioAnalyzer, 500ng of total underwent polyA selection and Truseq library preparation according to instruction provided by Illumina (TruSeq™ RNA Sample Prep Kit v2), with 6 cycles of PCR. Samples were barcoded and run on a Hiseq 2000 in a 75bp/75bp Paired end run, using the TruSeq SBS Kit v3 (Illumina).  An average of 74 million paired reads were generated per sample. At the most the ribosomal reads represented 0.3% and the percent of mRNA bases was closed to 55% on average.	null	Basecalls performed using CASAVA version 1.4; Reads were mapped to the human genome (Hg19) using STAR 2.3.0e with default mapping parameters; Read counts were generated from mapped reads using HT-Seq count; Genome_build: Hg19; Supplementary_files_format_and_content: Txt files containing total read counts per gene from HT-Seq counts using mode = "union"	Name: Jeffrey Zhao; Email: zhaoy@mskcc.org; Department: Genomics Core; Institute: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center; Address: 1275 York Avenue; City: New York; State: NY; Zip/postal_code: 10065; Country: USA

NE MTT	GSM1366427	GSE56657	GPL14761	20	6	Homo sapiens	tissue: Illeum; tumor type: Small intestinal neuroendocrine tumor; donor age: 73; gender: Male; synaptofysin staining: +; chromogranin staining: +; serotonin staining: +; cd117 staining: -; ppp staining: -; vip staining: -; ghrelin staining: -; cka staining: NA.	Public on Apr 10 2014	2014-04-09	2014-04-11	SRA	Illeum	null	Immediately after tumor resection, tumor tissue samples from the surgical specimens were placed in RNAlater® for overnight incubation. Samples were subsequently stored at 80°C until RNA was extracted using TRIzol.	Tumor sample obtained from a patient undergoing surgery at the Department of Surgical Gastroenterology, Rigshospitalet.	Ts at the begining of reads were trimmed from sequenced reads; Trimmed reads were mapped to the genome (hg19) with HeliSphere software using a seed length of 18nt and allowing only one mismatch in the seed region.; Only uniquely mapped reads with a minimum length of 21nt and a minimum score of 4 where further analyzed.; Reads arising from internal priming events were further discarded.; To identify polyA sites, read starts that were than 24nt apart were iteratively clustered. Cleavage sites were defined as the median position of the cleavage sites in the cluster.; Genome_build: hg19; Supplementary_files_format_and_content: Bed files of mapped reads; Supplementary_files_format_and_content: Bed files of polyA site clusters. The score represents the number of reads in each cluster.	Name: Mireya Plass; Email: mplass@binf.ku.dk; Institute: University of Copenhagen; Address: Ole Maaloes Vej 5; City: Copenhagen; Zip/postal_code: 2200; Country: Denmark

H3K27ac_ChIPseq_Human_rep1	GSM1375210	GSE49624,GSE57095	GPL9115	24	2	Homo sapiens	donor age: adult; cell type: sperm; chip antibody: H3K27ac; chip antibody vendor: Active Motif; chip antibody cat. #: # 39135	Public on May 19 2014	2014-04-25	2014-05-19	SRA	H3K27ac_ChIPseq_Human	null	Lysates were clarified from sonicated nuclei and histone-DNA complexes were isolated with antibody.; Libraries were prepared according to Illumina's instructions accompanying the DNA Sample Kit (Part# 0801-0303). Briefly, DNA was end-repaired using a combination of T4 DNA polymerase, E. coli DNA Pol I large fragment (Klenow polymerase) and T4 polynucleotide kinase. The blunt, phosphorylated ends were treated with Klenow fragment (32 to 52 exo minus) and dATP to yield a protruding 3- 'A' base for ligation of Illumina's adapters which have a single 'T' base overhang at the 3’ end. After adapter ligation DNA was PCR amplified with Illumina primers for 15 cycles and library fragments of ~250 bp (insert plus adaptor and PCR primer sequences) were band isolated from an agarose gel. The purified DNA was captured on an Illumina flow cell for cluster generation. Libraries were sequenced on the Illumina HiSeq 2000 following the manufacturer's protocols.	processed data file: H3K27ac_EnrichedRegions.txt	ChIP-seq data processing and analysis was performed as previously described in Hammoud et al., 2009.  Briefly, differential enrichment between histone ChIP-seq dataset and mononucleosomal control datasets (from GSE15690) were determined with ScanSeqs (USeq), and statistically enriched peaks were called with EnrichedRegionMaker (USeq).; Genome_build: hg18; Supplementary_files_format_and_content: Enrichment were determined with ScanSeqs (USeq), and statistically enriched peaks were called with EnrichedRegionMaker (USeq). Useq files were generated as part of the USeq software collection ChIPseq pipeline.	Name: Diana,HP,Low; Email: dlow@imcb.a-star.edu.sg; Laboratory: Ernesto Guccione; Department: Chromatin, Epigenetics & Differentiation; Institute: Institute of Molecular and Cell Biology; Address: #03-06, 61 Biopolis Drive, Proteos; City: Singapore; Zip/postal_code: 138673; Country: Singapore
